STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
October 22, 2025
Carey JO Adrianse
MECOSTA/OSCEOLA DHHS
800 WATER TOWER RD,
BIG RAPIDS, MI, 49307-2161
Re: License #: CP540201288
Dear Carey JO Adrianse:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
October 21, 2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 S. Elmwood, Ste. 11
Traverse City, MI 49684
enclosure
2

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12312 Foster parent training
• (4) At least 1 adult member of the household must have training in and
maintain a current certification in first aid and cardiopulmonary resuscitation
from the American Heart Association or the American Red Cross, or other
institution approved by the department.
Two of three foster home files reviewed did not have verification of current
CPR/First Aid.
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation
• (4) An agency shall document placement specifications consistent with the
information contained in the reevaluation. The placement specifications must
include all the following:
• (a) The age, number, SOGIE, race, ethnic background, and
characteristics of children preferred by the applicants.
One of three foster home files reviewed did not document preferred placement
specifications regarding SOGIE.
2

CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
• (6) An agency shall do all the following:
• (b) Inform the foster parent, in writing, that the foster parent has a right
to have his or her written response included as an attachment to the
report required by subrule (5) of this rule.
Two of two special evaluations reviewed did not inform the foster parent in writing of
their right to have a written response included as an attachment to the report.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the following information
before the placement or replacement of a child:
• (a) Child's name.
• (b) Child’s date of birth.
• (c)Available known information about the child’s health.
• (d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
• (e) All known emotional and psychological factors relating to the care
of the child.
• (f) All known behaviors of the child.
• (g) Circumstances necessitating placement or replacement of the
child.
• (h) Any other known information to enable the foster parent to provide
a stable, safe, and healthy environment for the foster child and the
foster family, including information about siblings who do not reside in
the foster home as provided in federal law.
Two of three foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver
was provided the information in subsections (a-h) of this rule prior to placement.
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living agreement
• (2) The agreement must be signed and dated by the youth and the social
service worker. The agreement must be reviewed with the youth at least once
every 90 calendar days and a copy provided to the youth.
Two of three independent living files reviewed did not have documentation the
independent living contract was updated and provided to youth every 90 days as
required.
3

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• There was no technical assistance requested or required.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• There was no consultation requested or required.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The
agency renewal inspection was completed on 10/29/24 and the CAP was
approved on 11/23/24. The agency was cited for 5 violations, none of which were
repeated this year. In 2023, 7 violations were established, none of which were
repeated this year.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator assessment was reviewed. The chief administrator
indicated the CAP that was developed from the previous year's audit has been
helpful in addressing areas of noncompliance. The CAP was developed as a team
and included new strategies for tracking such as mandatory scheduled file audit
days each month. In addition, the agency increased calendar reminders and
increased emphasis on supervisor oversight and accountability.
Financial Overview
NA
Staff and Youth Interviews
Interviews were conducted with two staff via telephone. Staff reported feeling
supported by supervision as well as coworkers. Pairing experienced workers with
new staff for mentoring was stated as being specifically helpful. Staff reported no
concerns with regard to the local office but expressed uncertainty about upcoming
changes statewide to foster care, specifically pod.
4

Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care and licensing. All files were stored securely and there is a
cross shredder for CHRI.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were 4 safety alerts identified.
Safety Alert #1: The home of unlicensed relative caregiver was found to have
cleaning products that were not secure and out of reach of child.
Resolution: A safety latch was put on the knobs of cabinet to prevent the child from
being able to access. In addition, safety magnetic locks were provided as an
alternative to use on the cabinet in the event the child is able to figure out how to
open the safety latch. The agency provided a picture for verification.
Safety Alert #2: The home of unlicensed, unrelated caregiver was found to be in
need of a medication lock box.
Resolution: The caregiver obtained a large lock box in addition to two smaller lock
boxes. The lock boxes are able to securely store all of the home's medications and
supplements. The agency provided a picture for verification.
Safety Alert #3: The home of unlicensed relative caregiver was missing a carbon
monoxide detector as well as locks on the kitchen cabinet with cleaning supplies.
Resolution: Both issues were rectified during home visit with DCWL Agency Analyst.
Safety Alert #4: Licensed foster home was missing smoke detector in 3 required
locations including between the master bedroom and rest of the home, between the
children's bedroom and rest of home and was also missing in the basement.
Resolution: Two smoke detectors were installed during a home visit on 9/17/2025.
One was installed outside the master bedroom, and the other was installed between
the children's bedrooms. The missing smoke detector in the basement was resolved
during DCWL Agency Analyst home visit. A special evaluation was also initiated
(2025SEC0001038). The home was found to be in violation of licensing rules
400.9304-1-a and 400.9304-1-b. A CAP was completed on 10/5/2025.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
5
